title: Disease Steps for Multiple Sclerosis
description: Assesses MS disease progression based on patient's ambulatory ability

parameters.name: disease_step
parameters.description: Patient's current disease step based on ambulatory ability assessment

result.name: disease_step_score
result.description: Disease Steps score (0-6 or U for unclassifiable)

ranges.interpretation: Normal neurologic function with no activity limitations. Patient functions normally in all activities of daily living.
Mild disability with minimal symptoms or neurologic signs. Patient may have minor complaints but maintains normal function in most activities.
Moderate disability with visibly abnormal gait. Patient has noticeable walking difficulties but remains ambulatory without assistance.
Early cane use with intermittent need for unilateral support. Patient requires walking aid occasionally but not continuously.
Late cane stage with continuous dependence on unilateral support. Patient requires walking aid for most or all ambulation.
Bilateral support required with need for two canes, crutches, or walker. Patient has significant mobility impairment but remains ambulatory.
Wheelchair dependent with severely limited mobility. Patient requires wheelchair for most activities and has minimal ambulatory function.

references: Hohol MJ, Orav EJ, Weiner HL. Disease steps in multiple sclerosis: a simple approach to evaluate disease progression. Neurology. 1995 Feb;45(2):251-5. doi: 10.1212/wnl.45.2.251.

Learmonth YC, Motl RW, Sandroff BM, Pula JH, Cadavid D. Validation of patient determined disease steps (PDDS) scale scores in persons with multiple sclerosis. BMC Neurol. 2013 Apr 25;13:37. doi: 10.1186/1471-2377-13-37.

Hohol MJ, Orav EJ, Weiner HL. Disease steps in multiple sclerosis: a longitudinal study comparing disease steps and EDSS to evaluate disease progression. Mult Scler. 1999 Oct;5(5):349-54. doi: 10.1177/135245859900500508.
formula: Direct mapping of patient's ambulatory ability to corresponding Disease Steps category (0-6 or U for unclassifiable)
notes: Designed as a simpler alternative to the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS)
Excellent inter-rater reliability (kappa = 0.8) compared to EDSS (kappa = 0.54)
Provides more uniform patient distribution across disability levels
Can be used for therapeutic decision-making and monitoring treatment response
Patient-Determined Disease Steps (PDDS) version allows for self-assessment
Focuses specifically on mobility and ambulatory function
Scale correlates well with quality of life and functional status measures
Useful for tracking disease progression over time in clinical and research settings
